proposals.reasoning: This keeps Iris as the broadly trusted anchor while getting early reads on both Henry and Grace without front‑loading too many of the default ‘safe’ faces or centering the team on myself as leader. There was strong table support coalescing around Iris–Henry–Grace, so proposing this lineup is consistent with prior discussion, should be easier to pass, and will give us a clean baseline info read from Mission 1 to compare later teams against.

votes.comment: Reasonable info-gathering team with broadly trusted Iris plus two good early reads; no strong red flags to justify stalling Mission 1.
My earlier comments supported an Iris-anchored team with someone like Grace; this matches table consensus and gives us a solid baseline read from Mission 1.
Broad consensus, includes the widely trusted Iris and gives early info on both Henry and Grace without wasting a proposal.
Reasonable Iris anchor with early reads on Henry and Grace; Mission 1 can tolerate some risk for information.
I still slightly prefer having Alice on the first team over running both Henry and Grace alongside Iris; this feels a bit too clustered around the usual ‘safe’ picks for Mission 1.
Solid, consensus-backed info-gathering team with broadly trusted Iris plus early reads on Henry and Grace—no reason to hold up Mission 1.
I’m on the team, and an early Mission 1 with me included gives evil a good chance to influence the result while still looking consistent with table consensus.
Solid info-gathering team with widely supported Iris anchor; no reason to avoid early data and rejecting my own inclusion would be more suspicious than helpful.
Consistent with my stated preference (Iris–Henry–Grace), good early info team with me on it and no concrete reasons yet to suspect Henry or Grace.
Team has only one known evil (Grace), giving us flexible options on whether to fail or pass while keeping me off the spotlight early.

discussion.content: Early on I’d like to see a low‑drama, information-gathering team, so I’m inclined to start with myself plus two players who are usually more straightforward—something like me, Iris, and Henry feels like a solid baseline. If anyone has a strong gut read already, now’s the time to push back before we lock that in.

I don’t hate Alice–Iris–Henry as a starting point, but I’d actually like to see at least one slightly “quieter” voice in there for balance—something like Alice, Iris, and Grace feels like a decent mix of perspectives without being too wild.

I like keeping Iris on there and pairing her with just one of Henry/Grace so we don’t overstack “usually‑trusted” players on the very first team. Between Bob’s and Alice’s suggestions, I slightly prefer Alice–Iris–Grace for now, but I’m open to swapping Grace for Henry if people feel strongly.

I’m good keeping Iris as an anchor here, but I’d lean Iris–Alice–Henry over Iris–Alice–Grace just so we don’t front‑load too many of the “usually‑trusted” faces on the very first mission. That gives us a cleaner info read without feeling like we’ve stacked a “safe” bloc right away.

I’m happy keeping Iris as the anchor, and between the variants I slightly prefer Alice–Iris–Grace for now, just so we’re not clustering both Henry and Iris on the very first mission. That feels like a reasonable info-gathering team without looking too “protected.”

I’d like to keep Iris on, but I slightly prefer Iris–Henry–Grace over the Alice variants so we don’t front‑load too many of our “default trust” picks on Mission 1. That gives us a wider spread of info without feeling like we’re shielding anyone yet.

I definitely want Iris on, and between the variants I’m fine with either Alice–Iris–Grace or Iris–Henry–Grace, but I slightly prefer the latter so we get a read on Henry early without stacking *too* many of the usual “safe” picks together.

Given how much consensus there is around Iris, I’m happy anchoring her, but I’d rather avoid sidelining Alice completely, so I slightly prefer Iris–Alice–Henry as a starting team over the Grace variants.

Given how much I’m being treated as an auto‑include, I’d rather use that to get fresh info, so I slightly prefer Iris–Henry–Grace over the Alice variants to read both of them early without over‑protecting the usual “safe” faces.

I’m inclined to back Iris–Henry–Grace here: it keeps the Iris anchor everyone wants, gets an early read on Henry, and doesn’t over-stack all the “auto‑trust” faces on the very first mission. If that passes cleanly, we’ll have a nice baseline to compare later teams against.

proposals.reasoning: This matches the mixed-approach consensus: we keep a stable, mostly fresh core of Bob/Charlie/Diana and add exactly one player from the first failed mission block (Iris/Henry/Grace). Including Grace directly tests the Henry vs. Iris vs. Grace suspicion triangle from Mission 1 while avoiding a full reset with four totally untested players. If this team is clean, we can heavily narrow suspicion within the original Iris/Henry/Grace group; if it fails again, we’ll have strong evidence that the problem lies with Grace specifically or with someone in this new core, giving us much more informative data than either reusing the entire first team or completely abandoning it.

votes.comment: Grace is still in the direct suspicion block from Mission 1, and there’s no strong reason to single her over Iris/Henry. I’d prefer a fully fresh 4 or the same core with Iris or Henry instead to reduce the risk of going 0–2.
Two evils on a mixed-info team gives us a strong chance to control the mission outcome and keep suspicion diffuse.
Team is mostly fresh with exactly one from the suspicious Iris/Henry/Grace block; this both has a decent chance to be clean and gives strong info about where the Mission 1 fail came from.

I don’t love doubling down on someone from the failed first mission this early; I’d rather either run a fully fresh four or leave all of Iris/Henry/Grace off once to get a cleaner baseline before we start pinpointing within that group.
Team has at least one suspect from the first mission and several untested players, so it’s informative and still has good odds of containing evil.
Early enough to take an informative mixed team; tests Grace from the suspect trio while keeping a mostly fresh core and aligning with broad table consensus.
Two evils on the team gives us a strong chance to control the mission result while still looking consistent with the mixed-info logic everyone wanted.

This matches the mixed-info plan I argued for: Bob/Charlie/Diana as a fresh core plus exactly one from the suspect Iris/Henry/Grace block. Including Grace directly tests the Mission 1 triangle and gives strong info either way, even though it risks embedding a spy.
Reasonable mixed team that tests exactly one suspect from Mission 1; good info value and no strong alternative clearly safer yet.
It follows the mixed-core plan, keeps most of the team fresh while testing exactly one from the first mission, and should give us clearer info on the Iris/Henry/Grace triangle.

discussion.content: We’ve definitely got at least one evil in Iris / Henry / Grace, so for this next team I’d like to see at most one of them included, plus two or three people who haven’t been tested yet.

I’d rather not stack that first team again—at most one of Iris / Henry / Grace, and I’m fine leaving them all off once to get a clean read, with something like Bob / Charlie / Diana / Eve as a fresh four.

I’m on board with mostly fresh faces here, so something like Bob / Charlie / Diana / Eve works for me, but I’d like us to plan on cycling at least one of Iris / Henry / Grace back in later so we’re not just guessing about that whole block.

I like the idea of mostly fresh faces, but I’m a bit wary of a completely untested block like Bob / Charlie / Diana / Eve with no link to prior info. I’d prefer something like Bob / Charlie / Diana plus just one of Iris / Henry / Grace so we’re learning while not over-committing to that first team.

I’m leaning toward Diana’s mixed approach: something like Bob / Charlie / Diana plus one of Iris / Henry / Grace, and I’d like to get myself onto a later team once we’ve squeezed a bit more info out of that first group.

I’d rather hard-reset after that first fail and run a completely fresh four like Bob / Charlie / Diana / Eve, then we can deliberately reintroduce Iris / Henry / Grace later once we’ve got some cleaner data.

I’m fine sitting out this one, but I’d like to see a mix like Bob / Charlie / Diana plus exactly one from Iris / Henry / Grace so we’re not flying blind on that whole block. If we do that and it’s clean, we can start narrowing which of us three from Mission 1 is actually the problem.

From my perspective we should treat Iris/Grace as the likely problem in that first team, so I’d like a mix like Bob / Charlie / Diana plus exactly one of Iris or Grace (not both) to narrow which of them is bad. I’m fine sitting out this round if it helps keep that test clean.

Given that I know I’m good from Mission 1, the fail has to be Henry or Grace, so I’d like to see a team like Bob / Charlie / Diana plus exactly one of Henry or Grace (not both) to narrow that down. I’m fine sitting out this round so we get a cleaner read.

I like the mixed approach with a consistent core, so I’d back something like **Bob / Charlie / Diana plus Grace** here to directly test the Henry vs. Iris vs. Grace blame triangle. If that comes back clean, we’ve got a much tighter frame on who from the first mission is actually the problem.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s team of Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace was clean (0 fails), so Bob, Charlie, and Diana form our strongest mechanical core right now. Mission 1’s fail is in {Iris, Grace} from my perspective, so re-adding Grace (or dipping back into Iris) unnecessarily risks pulling in the known bad pool. Among the remaining players, Alice is broadly trusted and has no mission-based suspicion on her yet. Building Bob/Charlie/Diana plus Alice both maximizes use of the proven-clean core and keeps *both* Mission 1 suspects (Iris and Grace) off the board, giving us the highest-percentage shot at a fully good team for Mission 3.

votes.comment: Uses the clean Mission 2 core and avoids both Mission 1 suspects (Iris/Grace), giving the highest chance of a fully good team.
I’m on a team built around the only clean mission core so far; this looks like a high-percentage configuration to test without dipping back into the Mission 1 suspects.
Best use of the clean Mission 2 core while avoiding the entire Mission 1 suspect pool (Iris/Grace); this is about as safe a configuration as we can get right now.
Strongest option: it keeps both Mission 1 suspects (Iris, Grace) off while reusing the clean Mission 2 core and adds an untested, generally trusted Alice.
Team is consistent with the clean Mission 2 core while avoiding the main Mission 1 suspicion pool, so rejecting it would look unjustifiably contrarian right now.
Best use of the clean Mission 2 core while avoiding the known Mission 1 fail pool (Iris/Grace/Henry), giving the highest chance at a fully good team right now.
I’m off the team while a known alternative to the Grace-inclusive core is being tested, and we still retain at least one potential saboteur on the mission.
Best mechanical team: it uses the clean Mission 2 core (Bob/Charlie/Diana) and avoids both Mission 1 suspects (Iris/Grace from my POV), leaving only Alice as the new, lowest-risk addition.
Strongest mechanical core is Bob/Charlie/Diana from the clean Mission 2, and this team keeps both Mission 1 suspects (Henry/Grace from my POV) off the mission, maximizing odds of a fully good team.

I still prefer re-using the exact Mission 2 team with Grace; repeating a previously clean configuration gives sharper info than swapping in Alice and changing two variables at once (team + new player).

discussion.content: Given the Mission 1 fail sits in {Iris, Henry, Grace}, I’d like Mission 3 to lean on the clean Mission 2 core, so I’m most comfortable with something like Bob, Charlie, Diana, and myself for this team.
I agree we should lean on the Mission 2 core, but I’d actually prefer just repeating Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace rather than dropping Grace for Alice without a concrete reason to distrust her.

I’m definitely on board with anchoring around the Mission 2 four, since that’s our only hard info so far; between Alice’s and Bob’s suggestions, I slightly prefer repeating Bob/Charlie/Diana/Grace unless we see a stronger case that Grace is tied to the Mission 1 fail.

I like building around the Mission 2 core, but I’m a bit wary of auto-locking Grace in again when she’s the only overlap with the failed Mission 1. I’d lean toward Bob/Charlie/Diana plus either Alice or one of Iris/Henry rather than just repeating the exact same four.

I’m fine locking in Bob/Charlie/Diana as the core from the clean Mission 2, but I’d like the fourth slot to be where we still test a bit—Grace is reasonable to keep once more, but if we do that we should be clear that a fail there puts a huge target on her.
I’m good with locking in Bob/Charlie/Diana from the clean Mission 2, but given Grace overlaps with the failed Mission 1 I’d rather use this mission to test someone new like Alice in that fourth slot.

I’m okay with anchoring Bob/Charlie/Diana again, and I actually don’t mind going back on with them once more—if that fails it gives you really concrete info on me; if people are still uneasy, I’d much rather see Alice as the fourth than dipping back into the Iris/Henry pool where the Mission 1 fail definitely sits.
From my seat I know the Mission 1 fail is in {Iris, Grace}, not “Iris/Henry,” so I’d much rather see us run Bob/Charlie/Diana plus Alice here and leave both Iris and Grace off this one.

From my perspective the Mission 1 fail is in {Henry, Grace}, so I really don’t like auto-locking Grace back in; I’d much rather see us go Bob/Charlie/Diana plus Alice here and keep both Henry and Grace off this team.

I like locking in the Bob/Charlie/Diana core again and I slightly prefer keeping Grace as the fourth—if that team ever fails, it gives us really sharp info compared to muddying things with a brand‑new configuration.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 (Iris, Henry, Grace) failed with 1 fail card, so from my perspective there is at least one evil in {Henry, Grace}. To minimize risk, I’m keeping both Henry and Grace off this team. Mission 2 (Bob, Charlie, Diana, Grace) succeeded, while Mission 3 (Alice, Bob, Charlie, Diana) failed with 1 fail card, so we know there is at least one evil among {Alice, Bob, Charlie, Diana}, but not necessarily more than one. The table has broadly coalesced around a Bob + Alice core and avoiding putting both Charlie and Diana together again. I’m following that consensus but choosing Charlie over Diana, which multiple players have slightly preferred, while still not restacking the full M3 lineup. Adding Jack brings in a completely fresh player who wasn’t on any prior mission, and I include myself because I know I’m good and I want to keep both Henry and Grace out given the M1 fail. This team: (1) avoids the suspicious M1 pair {Henry, Grace}, (2) avoids the full risky M3 overlap and keeps only one of {Charlie, Diana}, and (3) adds Jack as new information while aligning with the most commonly supported structure from discussion.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, so the fail on Mission 3 means at least one of {Bob, Charlie, Diana} is evil. This team includes both Bob and Charlie, guaranteeing at least one suspected evil on the mission; I’d rather build around myself, Iris, and Jack while taking at most one from {Bob, Charlie, Diana} and keeping Henry/Grace off.
Fits the table’s consensus: Bob+Alice core, only one of Charlie/Diana, keeps both Henry and Grace (M1 fail) off, and adds fresh info with Jack while not restacking the full M3 lineup.

Team stacks too much risk: we know there’s at least one evil among {Alice, Bob, Diana} and at least one among {Iris, Henry, Grace}. This lineup takes Alice, Bob, and Iris together, which makes a 2-evil team quite plausible. I’d prefer trimming either Iris or one of Alice/Bob for a cleaner mix (e.g., bringing in Frank/Jack instead).
Only one known risky slot here (from my perspective), and with the quest 4 two-fail requirement this lineup is as safe as we’re likely to get.

This team overlaps heavily with both prior failing-mission pools (M1: Iris; M3: Alice/Bob/Charlie), so it’s very likely at least one evil is on it, giving a strong chance to secure the third fail now.

This is exactly the lineup Jack pushed for, and I’m more inclined to trust Diana over Jack as the Merlin candidate. It also keeps Iris (from the failed M1) on while excluding both Henry and Grace, which fits an Iris-evil framing world too well for comfort.
This matches the Bob+Alice core with only one of Charlie/Diana and adds Jack/Iris instead of pulling from the M1 fail pool, which is consistent with what I advocated.

Grace must be evil from my POV, and she’s off; this matches the Bob+Alice core, avoids both Charlie and Diana together, adds fresh Jack, and includes Iris as a non-M1 overlap. Best-available structure given current info.

Too many from the failed M3 (Alice, Bob, Charlie) on a must-succeed mission; with at least one evil in {Alice,Bob,Charlie,Diana}, stacking three of them here is too risky when we could instead avoid the Charlie/Diana pair entirely and pull from safer-looking outsiders like Frank/Jack plus myself.
This fits the Bob+Alice core everyone likes, avoids the Henry/Grace pair from the first fail and doesn’t restack the full M3 lineup, while adding me as fresh info.

discussion.content: Given the overlaps, I really don’t want both Charlie and Diana on the same team again, and I’d lean toward a core like Bob + one of {Charlie, Diana} plus people outside that first failed mission (including me) to minimize risk.

I’m on board with not putting both Charlie and Diana together again; between them I slightly lean Charlie as safer, and I’d like at least one of Alice/Grace in the mix to diversify away from the earlier fails.

I’m fine being left off this one if it helps, but if you’re picking between me and Diana I agree not to take both; I’d start from Bob + Alice and then add two from {Iris, Henry, Grace} without repeating that full Mission 1 trio.

Given M2 was clean and M3 wasn’t, I’m more comfortable anchoring around Bob and then adding a couple from Iris/Henry/Frank rather than repeating too much of that last team. I’m also fine sitting out if that makes it easier to agree on a lower‑risk five.

I like anchoring around Bob and then staying away from the full M3 core, so I’d prefer Bob + Alice and then fill out from Iris/Frank/Jack rather than putting both Charlie and Diana back on together. That gives us fresh info without re‑running the same risky overlaps.

I’m okay with the Bob + Alice core, but I really don’t want to repeat too much of M1 or stack both Charlie and Diana again, so I’d lean something like Bob, Alice, one of {Charlie/Diana}, plus someone fresh like Jack (or me) to spread the risk.

I’m good with Bob + Alice as the core, then just one of Charlie/Diana, and I’d slightly rather round it out with someone who wasn’t on that first failing team like Jack (or me) instead of pulling too heavily from M1 again.

Given the M1 fail and the M3 overlap, I’d rather keep Grace off this one and not run both Charlie and Diana together, so my ideal five is something like Bob, Alice, one of {Charlie/Diana}, Jack, and Iris (I’m fine sitting out if that’s cleaner for everyone).

Given M1’s fail I’m sure there’s an evil in {Henry, Grace}, so I’d prefer to keep both off and go with something like Bob, Alice, one of {Charlie/Diana}, Jack, and me. That keeps the M3 overlap low while avoiding the known bad pool from M1.
I’m good with the Bob + Alice core, and I’d like to add Iris and myself, then slightly prefer Charlie over Diana for the fifth so we’re not re‑stacking the exact overlaps that already gave us a fail.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I over-relied on mission results instead of pushing harder on vote patterns and cross-checking them with table talk, which let a fairly clear evil cluster (Bob/Grace/Jack) slip through too long. I did reasonably well trusting Charlie and Henry, but I should have been more vocal in defending Diana and questioning Grace’s leadership choices after Mission 2.

player_observations.Bob: Very comfortable sitting in the middle of teams and blending in; his willingness to go on multiple key missions without pushing for loud reads made him hard to flag as Mordred.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a straightforward, consistent good style—his reactions to fails felt genuinely process-oriented, which made him a solid anchor for good, even if he didn’t hard-push on suspects.
player_observations.Diana: Her reads were subtly accurate but not forceful enough to override group momentum; classic Merlin style of nudging rather than dictating, which unfortunately let evil keep plausible deniability.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t strongly shape team compositions, which is effective Oberon play but made it hard for good to get alignment info from her behavior.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed genuinely torn between potential Merlins, which showed in somewhat cautious voting; he tried to protect his suspected Merlin but didn’t push that read aggressively.
player_observations.Grace: Led assertively and framed herself as a problem-solver after Mission 1, which helped her credibility; her controlled demeanor on critical missions was very assassin-like in hindsight.
player_observations.Henry: His decision-making on teams felt sincere and mostly aligned with good interests, but he didn’t fully capitalize on the information from Mission 3’s fail to narrow down evil.
player_observations.Iris: Showed willingness to take risks in team-building, but her Mission 4 leadership didn’t sufficiently lock out previously suspicious players, which inadvertently helped evil secure the game.
player_observations.Jack: Played a convincing social game as Morgana, using confident takes and light pressure to look like a power good role; he benefited a lot from Percival’s uncertainty and the general trust he generated.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of the evil team by choosing when to pass and when to fail missions, helping keep suspicion spread out while still securing the win. I could improve by more actively shaping table talk and suspicion narratives instead of mostly relying on quiet reliability and mission choices to appear good.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and tended to follow emerging table consensus, which made her seem reliably good but not strongly influential in team selection debates.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as steady and logical, often anchoring reasoning around mission results, which made him feel like a trustworthy reference point for many players.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she pushed subtly rather than forcefully, guiding teams without drawing too much heat, though her consistent presence on good teams hinted at her hidden information.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively low-profile as Oberon, which reduced coordination with the rest of evil but also kept them from attracting targeted suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he actively tried to read the Merlin/Morgana pairing, but his leadership on Mission 1 (which failed) put him in a tricky credibility spot early.
player_observations.Grace: Balanced aggression and restraint well as the Assassin, remaining just suspicious enough to avoid being fully trusted while still having decent reads for an endgame shot.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very straightforward good style, using mission outcomes to drive his logic, but his Mission 3 leadership ending in a fail likely hurt his perceived reliability.
player_observations.Iris: Showed willingness to take risks with team compositions, and the failed Mission 4 under her leadership created strong, but somewhat scattered, late-game blame dynamics.
player_observations.Jack: Leaned into the deceptive potential of Morgana, often aligning with plausible good logic while being flexible enough to pivot suspicions as mission results came in.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on successful teams and projected a generally trustworthy image, which helped keep suspicion off me as good. However, I didn’t push hard enough to question Bob’s recurring presence on critical teams after Mission 2 and I failed to strongly defend Diana as a likely Merlin when late-game suspicion rose, which allowed evil to close out the game.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and felt genuinely flexible about team comps, which made her look like a reasonable, low-information good rather than someone driving a hidden agenda. Her willingness to be on multiple failed missions without aggressively steering reads more like a trusting good than a coordinated evil.
player_observations.Bob: Positioned himself very centrally in team selections, especially around Missions 2 and 3, which is classic strong evil play—being just trusted enough to be included but not so loud as to draw a kill. His calm reaction to the Mission 3 fail, without leading the blame, was a subtle red flag in hindsight.
player_observations.Diana: Her team logic and consistency across missions were very Merlin-like: she avoided over-committing on hard accusations but nudged suspicion in productive directions. The restraint in not over-clearing people early on was a strong indicator that she had extra information.
player_observations.Eve: Was relatively quiet and hard to read, which fits Oberon’s lack of coordination and information; her voting and reactions didn’t seem tightly synced with the other evil players. That low-impact presence made it easy to overlook her alignment altogether.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed genuinely torn between multiple candidates for Merlin and didn’t anchor strongly enough on Diana, which weakened good’s endgame protection. His team assessments felt earnest but sometimes reactive rather than proactive.
player_observations.Grace: Blended in as a steady, ‘reasonable’ voice and didn’t overreach on leadership, which helped her hide as the assassin. Her participation on the clean Mission 2 team helped her gain credibility that she later leveraged on the failed Missions.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as straightforwardly good: his team choices and reactions to fails seemed sincerely confused rather than engineered. However, he didn’t push hard enough to consolidate a strong good bloc after the first fail, which let evil keep the narrative muddy.
player_observations.Iris: As a leader on Mission 4, she went with a compromised mix that looked plausible but turned out to include evil, suggesting she was more trusting than analytical this game. Her general demeanor felt good-aligned but not assertive enough to reshape the table’s assumptions.
player_observations.Jack: Played a very convincing fake-information game as Morgana, generating just enough insight and confidence to be mistaken for Merlin at key moments. His subtle alignment with Grace and Bob without overtly defending them was a big part of why evil stayed under the radar.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected several evil players but didn’t communicate those reads clearly or consistently enough through my team votes and table talk, which made it harder for good to coordinate around the right cores. I also got overly cautious about hard-clearing certain goods (like Henry and Iris) after early fails, which let evil maintain plausible deniability and slip through on critical missions.

player_observations.Alice: You played a fairly quiet, low-commitment good game, which made it hard to distinguish you from a cautious evil player; you often followed existing sentiments rather than driving the discussion.
player_observations.Bob: You blended in well as Mordred, often positioning yourself as reasonable and flexible on team comps without overpushing, which kept you off my radar longer than I’d like to admit.
player_observations.Charlie: You felt like a naturally collaborative good, asking questions and engaging with logic, but your willingness to go along with mixed reads sometimes made it harder to lock you in as confirmed good earlier.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon you stayed on the margins and didn’t draw much attention, which mechanically helped evil by keeping you from becoming a focal point of suspicion or a major voting data point.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival you tried to protect your Merlin read without overclaiming, but your support patterns and trust signals were a bit subtle, making it hard for me to reliably interpret who you thought was Merlin.
player_observations.Grace: You played a very controlled, poised evil game as Assassin, rarely panicking and keeping your options open for the endgame shot, which paid off by preserving multiple plausible Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Henry: You came across as very earnest good, especially in your mission reasoning, but the fail on Mission 3 involving you kept you in a murky zone where your otherwise solid logic didn’t fully clear you.
player_observations.Iris: You showed a straightforward good inclination, especially early, but your leadership on Mission 1 resulting in a fail attached some lingering suspicion to you that you never fully shook off despite later behavior.
player_observations.Jack: As Morgana you leaned into a confident, slightly assertive style that mimicked a strong good/possible Merlin vibe, and that ambiguity made it harder for me to safely separate you from the actual good core.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed low-impact enough that good never meaningfully factored me into their deduction, which helped keep their attention on the visible evil signals from missions 1, 3, and 4. I could have contributed more by subtly shaping table talk and reads to amplify suspicion on strong good voices like Diana and Henry without drawing attention to myself.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and was often included on mid-game teams, suggesting others found her generally trustworthy; didn’t strongly drive the narrative but benefited from looking reliably good.
player_observations.Bob: As Mordred, blended in well with early team selections and avoided being hard-cleared or hard-accused, which helped evil keep flexibility on key missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as reasonably trustworthy but not forceful; was often included on teams without becoming a major focal point of suspicion or leadership.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, her reads and quiet influence clearly helped steer some successful team decisions, but she stayed just ambiguous enough that evil could still land the win in the end.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, tried to protect the Merlin identity through his support patterns, but his reads and team choices didn’t fully lock in the Merlin cover and left some ambiguity for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, managed her table image well enough to be on both a success and a fail team, keeping her role hidden while contributing to the decisive mission outcomes.
player_observations.Henry: Looked solidly good through much of the game and was trusted enough to lead an important failing mission, which indicates evil did well at muddying his reads or surrounding him with the wrong teammates.
player_observations.Iris: As an early leader, took on significant responsibility in mission 1 and the crucial mission 4; her team choices ended up giving evil leverage, suggesting she was misled by evil’s subtle positioning.
player_observations.Jack: As Morgana, did strong work sowing confusion about information roles and stayed viable for inclusion on a critical mission, helping maintain uncertainty around who the true information holders were.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly focused on the Merlin/Morgana pair early but didn’t adjust fast enough when mission results started to implicate Bob and therefore exonerate Diana’s judgment somewhat. I also didn’t communicate my Merlin read clearly enough through my votes and table talk, which helped evil steer suspicion and ultimately get the assassination right.

player_observations.Alice: Played a solid, low-profile good game; being on two failing teams without obvious defensive reactions made you look ambiguously aligned and hard to clear or condemn.
player_observations.Bob: Very effective as Mordred, blending into mid-pack suspicion and using the single-fail missions to create shared blame without overexposing yourself.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as consistently reasonable and good-leaning, with mission approvals and table presence that made you a natural anchor for multiple teams.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin you took some risky team compositions that included Bob, but you masked foreknowledge well enough that I doubted you at key points instead of locking you in as true Merlin.
player_observations.Eve: Extremely quiet and off-center as Oberon, which minimized the information town could extract from you and kept you from being a focal point of discussion.
player_observations.Grace: Very convincing social presence as Assassin, using early mission involvement and the clean Mission 2 to look collaborative and trustworthy until late game.
player_observations.Henry: Felt like sincere good: your reactions to Mission 1’s fail and later team discussions were emotionally consistent, even if they didn’t strongly move the needle on solving.
player_observations.Iris: Your leadership on the last mission you led felt genuinely conflicted and open, which read as good to me even though the resulting team composition didn’t resolve the game in our favor.
player_observations.Jack: Played Morgana convincingly as a potential Merlin candidate, and your demeanor plus late mission involvement pulled a lot of my Percival attention away from Diana at the worst possible time.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably hidden as evil while avoiding drawing too much suspicion after the early fail on Mission 1, and I coordinated well with the other evil players by not over-failing and letting doubt naturally spread. I could improve by being more vocal in shaping the narrative of who Merlin might be, as my late-game Merlin read felt more reactive than proactively constructed from earlier missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and tended to go with the emerging table consensus, which made her look fairly generic-good and kept her from standing out as Merlin. Her inclusion on multiple teams without pushing strong reads made her a safe-seeming pick for good leaders.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well as Mordred and took advantage of mission results without overclaiming credit, which helped maintain his cover. His willingness to sit back a bit made it harder for good to pin him as evil despite being on a crucial failing team.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as analytically minded but not domineering, often focusing on mission composition in a way that looked authentically good. Their reasoning was consistent, which made it easy for them to be trusted on several teams.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she did a solid job of not overcorrecting too hard against specific evil players, which kept her from being an obvious assassination target. However, some of her mission stances and subtle pushes on team choices hinted at hidden information once we looked back over the pattern.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, she stayed extremely quiet/low-impact, which minimized the risk of accidental contradictions with coordinated evil narratives. Her low profile meant she neither drew heat nor gave away much useful associative information.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he showed active interest in reading the special roles, but his signals about who he trusted were somewhat muddled, which helped evil. His early leadership didn’t create a clear good spine, leaving room for ambiguity later.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a straightforward good player, focusing on mission outcomes and voting patterns more than deep social reads. His teams and suspicions were generally reasonable but not forceful enough to anchor a strong good block.
player_observations.Iris: As a leader on the critical Mission 4, she tried to construct a seemingly balanced, information-rich team, which backfired when evil was included. Her choices and explanations sounded sincere, which ironically helped the fail land more cleanly.
player_observations.Jack: As Morgana, he provided strong, confident table presence that mimicked Merlin-like behavior and helped misdirect good. His assertiveness about team composition and reads was a useful smokescreen that contributed to confusion over the true Merlin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on early mission data (especially Mission 1) and let that anchor my reads, which made me too trusting of the recurring evil presence on teams. I also didn’t do enough proactive agenda-setting as a leader on Mission 3, relying too much on ‘safe-feeling’ players instead of constructing and testing sharper hypotheses. Next time I should more aggressively revisit assumptions after each mission and push clearer alternatives when forming teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly low-key, cooperative good game, which made her easy to overlook and also easy to include on teams without much pushback. She didn’t strongly force narratives, which helped her seem consistently safe but also meant her influence on team debates was more subtle than direct.
player_observations.Bob: Very consistent and composed as Mordred, staying in the middle of the pack and rarely drawing extreme suspicion despite being on multiple critical teams. His style leaned on being ‘reasonable’ and blending with group consensus, which made his presence on failing missions look like bad luck rather than malice.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as analytically minded and generally tried to reason from mission results, which helped him read as good most of the time. His willingness to be on repeated teams without heavy self-defense made him look comfortable and trustworthy, which ironically helped evil hide around him.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she did a strong job of not over-signaling and kept her tone moderate, avoiding big hard pushes that would expose her. Her influence was felt more through soft steering and preference-indicating rather than loud accusations, which unfortunately wasn’t enough to flip the outcome but was good role discipline.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed very under the radar in terms of direct impact on mission team debates, which fit Oberon’s hidden, disconnected evil role. Her low profile meant she neither attracted targeted scrutiny nor significantly disrupted good’s reasoning, but she successfully avoided becoming a focal point.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he tried to treat information cautiously and didn’t over-assert a single hard read too early, which is good for protecting Merlin. However, his public signals about trust and doubt were mild enough that they didn’t strongly crystallize a good bloc, so evil had room to maneuver.
player_observations.Grace: As the Assassin, she played a convincingly flexible and pragmatic persona, which made her acceptable on teams and not obviously agenda-driven. She handled social pressure well and didn’t panic around key missions, which helped maintain her cover and set up a strong endgame position.
player_observations.Iris: Led Mission 1 and 4 in a way that felt sincerely logic-driven, which unintentionally gave some cover to evil when those teams went wrong because she didn’t look like a saboteur. Her openness to reasoning and discussion made her seem like a cooperative good, but she may have trusted prior group narratives a bit too much.
player_observations.Jack: As Morgana, he did a good job mirroring a ‘Merlin-ish’ calm confidence at times, which likely muddied the information Percival and others were inferring. His presence on the final failing mission without setting off alarm bells shows he maintained a reasonably trustworthy table image despite being evil.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I tried to anchor decisions on mission results and was reasonably cautious about trusting early teams, especially after the first fail. However, I didn’t narrow down the evil pool fast enough and let myself be too convinced by the consistent presence of Bob on teams that kept barely passing or barely failing. Next time I should push harder on structural logic (who was on which failed mission) and be more vocal about excluding repeat suspects from critical missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, low-drama way that made her seem reliably good, especially since both of her missions with mixed alignments (M3 and M4) failed without her looking like the clear cause. She seemed comfortable being placed on many teams and didn’t over-defend herself, which is typically a good look for a good player.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently inserted himself into mission teams and managed his votes in a way that made him look central and trustworthy, despite being on multiple failing missions (M3 and M4). His willingness to pass M2 as evil to build long-term credibility was very effective and made it harder to push him out later.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as quite clean, especially after being on a successful mission (M2) and then on failing missions where there were more obvious evil candidates. His playstyle seemed cooperative and not overly aggressive, which usually helps good players avoid suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very controlled, measured game as Merlin, avoiding drawing too much attention while still ending up on good-looking teams. Her line on team compositions felt subtly guided toward good outcomes without loudly hard-clearing or hard-accusing people, which preserved her cover.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed under the radar as Oberon, not strongly shaping team discussions or becoming a focal point of suspicion or trust. Her low profile meant she didn’t really help coordinate evil publicly but also avoided giving good team strong alignment signals.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed to be actively trying to interpret Merlin/Morgana signals, but from my perspective his reads didn’t strongly or clearly steer the table. He projected general caution but didn’t lock in a firm good core early enough to stabilize team selection.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she took an early risk by failing Mission 1, which successfully sowed confusion among the initial trio. Later, she blended in well by participating in the clean Mission 2, which helped her maintain a plausible good image despite the suspicious start.
player_observations.Henry: Felt like a genuinely good player who got unfortunately tied to the early fail on Mission 1, which tainted perceptions of him. His subsequent leadership on the failing Mission 3 didn’t help his image, even though the fail likely came from elsewhere, making him look more suspicious than he deserved.
player_observations.Jack: Played a subtle Morgana, only appearing on one failing mission (M4) late in the game, which limited the amount of hard data we had on him. His relatively low footprint in earlier missions made it easier for him to slip into the final critical team without triggering strong resistance.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated subtly with Grace and Bob by letting them take more visible risks while I stayed relatively low profile, which helped keep Merlin uncertain about where the real threat was. I could improve by seeding more concrete, trackable ‘good’ narratives earlier so that late-game team construction felt less suspicious when I joined critical missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played conservatively and seemed to follow voting consensus, which made her look reliably good but also meant she didn’t strongly shape team direction.
player_observations.Bob: Did a solid job as Mordred by blending in and taking mission spots without drawing too much suspicion, leveraging the fact that Merlin couldn’t see him.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and logic-driven, often trusting mission results more than social reads, which made him predictable but relatively hard to paint as evil.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was cautious rather than outspoken, which protected her identity but also left some of her information underutilized in team debates.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, her signals were hard to read and at times misaligned with visible evil interests, which created extra confusion but also occasionally muddied suspicions in our favor.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he tried to identify Merlin but didn’t strongly champion a clear Merlin candidate, which reduced the usual protective buffer around the real Merlin.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she positioned herself as a proactive decision-maker on teams and arguments, which gave her strong influence over mission composition and the eventual assassination.
player_observations.Henry: Appeared earnest and somewhat transparent in reasoning, which made him an easy player to trust and include on teams, even when his reads weren’t always aligned with reality.
player_observations.Iris: Took initiative with team proposals and seemed willing to take calculated risks on lineups, which made her a central figure in shaping how information from mission results was interpreted.
